Earth rotates _____° every day, or _____° every hour.
Earth rotates _____° in 5 hours.
It is the same time at all points on a __________. To the East the time is (earlier/later), to the west the time is (earlier/later).
What is Local Mean Time (LMT?)
questions.answer: The time along a selected meridian of longitude.

questions.question: LMT at all points on a meridian is (the same/different).
Time zones are referenced to _____, and go from _____ to _____.
Time zones are designated from letters from _____ to _____. New Zealand is in the _____ time zone. Greenwich is in the _____ time zone.
Time zones are normally _____°, or _____ hour(s) apart.
Which meridian does New Zealand use for its time zone?
When does NZST start/end. How far ahead/behind GMT is NZST?
questions.answer: First Sunday in April/last Sunday in September. 12 hours ahead of GMT.

questions.question: When does NZDT start/end? How far ahead/behind GMT is NZDT?
questions.answer: Last Sunday in September/first Sunday in April. 13 hours ahead of GMT.

questions.question: To convert NZST to GMT (add/subtract) _____ hours. To convert GMT to NZST (add/subtract) _____ hours.
To convert NZDT to GMT (add/subtract) _____ hours. To convert GMT to NZDT (add/subtract) _____ hours.
Where is the international date line, with what exceptions, and what causes the exceptions?
questions.answer: Following the 180° meridian. Once exception in each of the northern/southern hemispheres due to geography.

questions.question: When you travel East across the international date line, (add/subtract) a day.
When you travel West across the international date line (add/subtract) a day.
How long does it take the Earth to rotate 1 degree?
How many degrees does the Earth rotate in 1 minute?
How long does it take the Earth to rotate 1'? (NB. minute of longitude, not time).
What is the definition of sunrise?
questions.answer: Precise time the upper limb (first visible part) of the sun is visible on the horizon.

questions.question: What is the defintion of sunset?
questions.answer: Precise time the upper limb (last visible part) of the sun disappears below the horizon.

questions.question: Daylight is the time between the ____________________ and the ____________________.
questions.answer: Start of morning twilight. End of evening twilight.

questions.question: What is the sensible horizon?
questions.answer: A plane tangential to the Earth at the observer's location.

questions.question: How is the sensible horizon different to the visible horizon?
questions.answer: Visible horizon is slight curved due to Earth's curvature and refraction of light.

questions.question: What is MCT?
questions.answer: Morning Civil Twilight. Begins when the centre of the sun is 6° below the sensible horizon.

questions.question: What is ECT?
questions.answer: Evening Civil Twilight. Ends when the centre of the sun is 6° below the sensible horizon.

questions.question: As elevation increases, the start of MCT will be (earlier/later), and the end of ECT will be (earlier/later).
Twilight is (longer/shorter) in tropical regions than regions at higher/lower latitudes.
NZ twilight is longer in the (North/South).
Areas with the same LMT (on the same meridian) (will/will not) be in the same part of the day as each other. This is because __________.
questions.answer: Will not. The Earth's axis is tilted relative to the sun.

questions.question: What are B of MCT and E of ECT?
questions.answer: Beginning of Morning Civil Twilight. End of Morning Civil Twilight.

questions.question: In summer, B of MCT is (earlier/later) and E of ECT is (earlier/later). These differences are (significant/insignificant) in equatorial regions, and (significant/insignificant) nearer the poles.
In New Zealand, summer days in the south are (shorter/longer) than days in the north.
In New Zealand, winter days in the south are (shorter/longer) than days in the north.
What is an important consideration when descending into an aerodrome near ECT?
questions.answer: Daylight is longer at altitude, meaning it may still be daylight at cruise elevation, but after sunset at the aerodrome elevation.

questions.question: What are three considerations which can affect daylight conditions at a given location?
questions.answer: Altitude: daylight at altitude, after sunset at ground level. Atmospheric conditions: smog, preciptiation, cloud cover. Obstructions: can block daylight, resulting in earlier E of ECT.

questions.question: What side of a mountain range should you especially wary of flying on around ECT? Why?
questions.answer: Eastern side. Mountains can block the sun setting in the west, resulting in less amount of daylight at that location..

questions.question: Where can you find Daylight Zones and Tables? What do the figures represent?
questions.answer: AIPNZ Volume 4 GEN 2.7. B of MCT and E of ECT.

questions.question: What timezone are the values in the Daylight Zones and Tables?
If a flight is restricted to 'day only', when can it operate?
questions.answer: After B of MCT and before E of ECT.

questions.question: Moving eastward: (add/subtract) time. Moving westward (add/subtract) time.
Where are three places you can get an accurate time check?
questions.answer: Air Traffic Service unit. National radio programme, 6 'pips' on the hour. Industrial Research Limited.
